docs.lead_paragraph: Blood thinners and diabetes drugs cause most emergency hospital visits for drug reactions among people over 65 in the United States, a new study shows. Just four medications or medication groups -- used alone or together -- were responsible for two-thirds of emergency hospitalizations among older Americans, according to the report. At the top of the list was warfarin, also known as Coumadin, a blood thinner. It accounted for 33 percent of emergency hospital visits. Insulin injections were next on the list, accounting for 14 percent of emergency visits.

headline.main: 4 Drugs Cause Most E.R. Visits in Elderly

docs.abstract: Study published in the New England Journal of Medicine finds blood thinners, insulin injections, antiplatelet drugs and oral diabetes drugs account for two-thirds of all emergency room visits among Americans over age 65; study is co-authored by Dan Budnitz of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. (M)
